item.para: Communications between the Government of the Republic of Vietnam and other Governments are not all available to the Australian Government. The assistance being provided by other countries to the Republic of Vietnam, including assistance by other S.E.A.T.O. countries, was listed in a reply by Senator Paltridge on behalf of the Prime Minister to question No. 487 in the Senate in May. The principal developments since then have been the increase in military units supplied, especially by the United States, but also by Australia, New Zealand and the Republic of Korea.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Council for Educational Research. (Question No. 1409.)

talk.start.para: s asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: What annual Commonwealth grants have been made to the Australian Council for Educational Research in each of the last ten years?

Has his attention been drawn to the Director's statement in his 1965 annual report that as a direct result of increased interest in education generally, and in educational research in particular, there has been an increasing gap between the Council's resources and the demands made upon them?
Will the Government consider making' a substantially increased grant in the immediate future to this important research body?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: The grant to the Australian Council for Educational Research was £5,000 in the financial year 1955/56 and this was increased to £7,500 per annum in 1956/57 and has remained 'at £7,500 per annum since that time. The Commonwealth grant matches the total grants from the States up to the limit of £7,500.
Yes. " 3. The States and the Commonwealth are considering this.

talk.start.para: n asked the Minister for External Affairs, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that North Vietnam in May and June 1956, July 1957, March 1958, July 1959 and in 1960 called for free general elections by secret ballot, under the supervision of international inspectors?

Did North Vietnam explicitly accept the principle that all Vietnamese citizens, whether from the North or the South, had the right to canvas freely through the country through conference, leaflets, press, etc., and that the Government of the North and the Authorities of the South should ensure the liberty and the security of all citizens during their election activities?

Did the International Control Commission ever report that the Government of South Vietnam refused to enter into negotiations with North Vietnam for the purpose of holding free elections towards re-unification?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows - 1 and 2. The North Vietnamese authorities have frequently stated that they favoured free general elections for the unification of Vietnam. In contrast to their words, their actions, and particularly their repression of opposition in their own territory, clearly made the holding of genuinely free elections impossible. See the section on the "issue of elections" at pages 1-3 of the booklet " Studies on Vietnam " prepared by the Department of External Affairs, copies of which are in the Parliamentary Library.

item.para: No. The published reports of the International Control Commission referred to there being "no progress in the matter of the consultations and the elections".

talk.start.para: n asked the Minister for External Affairs, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that after 1956 the Government of South Vietnam refused to extend any facilities to the International Control Commission, as required under Article 25 of the Geneva Accords, thus preventing the Commission from investigating complaints concerning South Vietnamese reprisals and discrimination against persons on account of their activities during hostilities preceding the Geneva Agreement?
Was the International Control Commission allowed to operate freely in North Vietnam until the United States bombings began in February 1965?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: Although not a party to the Geneva Agreement the Government of South Vietnam, on 6th April 1956, declared that it would "continue to extend effective co-operation to the Commission, will ensure the security of its members and will to the fullest extent possible facilitate the accomplishment of its mission for peace." (See Department of External Affairs Select Documents on International Affairs, No. 1 of 1964, Vietnam Since the 1954 Geneva Agreements, at pages 25-26.) On the specific question of the complaints mentioned, the Government of the Republic of Vietnam took the view that its own complaints about North Vietnamese subversion in the South should first be investigated.
No. I shall quote, since Canada is a member of the International Commission, what the Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, Mr.

answer.para: Paul Martin, said on 5th April 196S, in commenting on Canada's work as a member of the Commission - "The work of the Commission has been hindered by North Vietnam. For years the Northern teams have not been allowed to conduct meaningful controls."

He went on: " In all cases, because the North Vietnamese authorities had been intent on the teams being as ineffective as possible, the team headquarters had been located in such a way as to ensure that Commission personnel would be as remote as possible from any installations which would be legitimate objects of Commission observations,"

talk.start.para: m asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: Was the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation undertaking research into blends when the Wool Marketing Committee of Enquiry was appointed in January 1961?
If so, what proportion of its wool research funds was devoted to such research?
If research was not being undertaken in January 1961, when did it commence such research?
What proportion of its wool research funds is at present devoted to such research?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: Yes.
Less than one per cent. of the total research effort relating to wool was concerned directly with research into blends.
Research of this kind was being undertaken in January 1961.
